'Regent' Juneberry.edible_use: The fruit is rich in iron and copper. It can be eaten raw or cooked. The leaves can be used as herbal tea.
'Regent' Juneberry.medicinal_use: Infusion of the inner bark is used as a treatment for eye infection.

Chokeberry.edible_use: The fruit has a high concentration of antioxidants and is best eaten after the first frost when it is fully ripe. Because it is rich in pectin, it can be used to make a jelly.
Chokeberry.medicinal_use: The pectin can also protect the body against radiation.
Chokeberry.other_use: The fruit's syrup can be used to create a natural purple dye.

Cornelian Cherry Dogwood.edible_use: The fruit is juicy, with an acidic flavour. The seeds can be roasted, ground into a powder, and used as a coffee substitute.
Cornelian Cherry Dogwood.medicinal_use: The bark is astringent, febrifuge, and nutritious. It is used to treat cholera. The flowers are used to treat diarrhea.

Forsythia.medicinal_use: The flowers have strong bactericidal and acaricidal properties which can be used for skincare. Washing your face with the flowers once a day can effectively reduce facial pigmentation, acne, and wrinkles.
Forsythia.other_use: The flowers can be used to create yellow dye. In addition, green dye can be extracted from the leaves and the stem.

'Indigo Gem' Honeyberry.edible_use: The fruits are high in Vitamin C, Vitamin A, fiber, and potassium. They can be used in various products such as pastries, jams, juice, and sauces.

Crab Apple.edible_use: The leaves can be used to make herbal tea.
Crab Apple.medicinal_use: The fruit is astringent and laxative. The crushed fruit pulp can be used as a poultice to heal inflammations or small flesh wounds.

'Blizzard' Mockorange.medicinal_use: The dried powdered roots can be mixed with oil and used as a rub on sores and swollen joints.
'Blizzard' Mockorange.other_use: The leaves and flowers are rich in saponins. When crushed and mixed with water, they produce a lather that is an effective cleaner. The fresh leaves can be used as a bar of soap.

Beach Plum.edible_use: The fruits are sweet, rich in Vitamin C, and have a high concentration of antioxidants.
Beach Plum.medicinal_use: The leaves can be used to make herbal tea to treat a sore throat and swelling of the mouth.
Beach Plum.other_use: A green dye can be obtained from the leaves. A dark green dye can be obtained from the fruit.

Azalea.medicinal_use: The leaves can be used as poultice to relieve arthritic pain and headaches.

Gooseberry.edible_use: The fruits are edible and can be used cosmetically in face-masks to rejuvenate the skin.
Gooseberry.other_use: A yellow dye can be obtained from the leaves. A black dye can be obtained from the fruit.

Rose.edible_use: The fruit is not very fleshy but it is rich in vitamins A, C, and E. It is also a good source of essential fatty acids. The seed is a good source of vitamin E; it can be ground and mixed with flour or added to other foods as a supplement. The leaves can be used for an infusion called 'Rose Tea.'

Elderberry.edible_use: The fruits are rich in vitamin C and are best when dried.
Elderberry.toxicity: The unripe fruit contains a toxic alkaloid and cyanogenic glycosides. These toxins are destroyed when the fruit is cooked. The leaves and stems are poisonous. The fruit has been known to cause an upset stomach.

False Spiraea.edible_use: Buds and leaves can be eaten if cooked.
False Spiraea.toxicity: The leaves and the flowers contain the toxin: hydrogen cyanide.

Pagoda Dogwood.medicinal_use: The inner bark can be used as a tea treat influenza, diarrhoea, headaches, voice loss, and reduce fevers. Some Native Americans used it as a eye wash. A compound infusion of the bark and roots has been used to treat childhood diseases and conditions such as measles and worms.
Pagoda Dogwood.other_use: The roots, mixed with vinegar, yield a light to dark brown dye.

Lilac.edible_use: Flowers are edible, raw or cooked. An essential oil is obtained from the flowers.
Lilac.medicinal_use: The bark or leaves can be chewed in order to treat a sore mouth.
Lilac.other_use: A green dye is obtained from the flowers. Green and brown dyes are obtained from the leaves. A yellow-orange dye is obtained from the twigs.

Highbush Blueberry.edible_use: The fruits are rich in vitamin C. They can be used in pies, pastries, cereals, and jellies. The fruit can also be dried and used like raisins. A tea is made from the leaves.
Highbush Blueberry.medicinal_use: Blueberry leaves are incredibly high in the phenolic compounds found in the antioxidant anthocyanins. They also enhance dopamine levels which support efficient memory, attention and problem solving functions.

Viburnum 'Wentworth'.edible_use: The fruits are rich in vitamin C and are best after the frost.
Viburnum 'Wentworth'.medicinal_use: An infusion of the roots is used to make a person vomit and to treat fevers. The inner bark is used to treat stomach cramps.

Baneberry.medicinal_use: As the leaves die back in the autumn, the roots are harvested and dried.
Baneberry.toxicity: The root is toxic in overdose; it should be used with caution and be completely avoided by pregnant women.

KIWI.edible_use: The fruit is rich in vitamin C and can be eaten raw or dried for later use. The plant is rich in sap and thus can be tapped and drunk in the spring.

Marshmallow.edible_use: The flowers and young leaves can be eaten and are often added to salads or boiled and fried. The root extract (halawa extract) is sometimes used as flavoring in a Middle Eastern snack called halva.

False Goat's Beard.edible_use: The young shoots are edible after they are cooked.

Goat's Beard.medicinal_use: The poulticed root is applied to Tease bee stings. A tea made from the roots is used to allay bleeding after child birth, to reduce profuse urination, and to treat stomach pains, diarrhea, fevers and internal bleeding. The tea is used externally to bathe swollen feet and rheumatic joints.

Brunnera.other_use: The roots can be used to make a red dye.

Goldenseal.medicinal_use: The root is used to treat disorders affecting the ears, eyes, throat, nose, stomach, and intestines.
Goldenseal.toxicity: The plant should not be used during pregnancy or by people with high blood pressure.
Goldenseal.other_use: A yellow dye can be obtained from the root.

Iris.edible_use: The roots are edible and have great quantities of starch.
Iris.toxicity: Some reports suggest that the plant might be poisonous.

Daisy.edible_use: The leaves can be eaten raw or cooked. Young spring shoots are finely chopped and added to salads and soups. The root can be consumed raw and the flowers can be tossed into a salad or pickled.
Daisy.other_use: The leaves and the roots can make yellow dye.

Peony.edible_use: The fallen flower petals are parboiled and sweetened, or cooked in various dishes.
Peony.medicinal_use: A tea made from the dried crushed petals is used as a cough remedy, and as a treatment for haemorrhoids and varicose veins.

Rodgersia.medicinal_use: In the medicinal tradition of China, Rodgersia aesculifolia has been employed in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, chronic bronchitis, dysentery, asthma, bronchial inflammation and chronic gastritis.

Lowbush Blueberry.edible_use: The fruit can be dried and used like raisins or eaten raw.
Lowbush Blueberry.medicinal_use: A tea made from the leaves can be used as a blood purifier and a treatment of infant's colic. It also has been used to induce labour and as a tonic after a miscarriage.

Maidenhair Fern.medicinal_use: The leaves can be used as tea or syrup to treat nasal congestion, asthma, and sore throats. The Native Americans chewed the fronds and then applied them to wounds to stop bleeding.
Maidenhair Fern.other_use: The leaves are also used as a hair conditioner. The stems have been used as a hair wash.

Bugleweed.medicinal_use: The whole plant is aromatic. It is harvested as it flowers in late spring and dried for later use. It is also commonly used fresh in ointments and medicated oils. It is widely used in various preparations against throat irritations and especially in the treatment of mouth ulcers.

Wood Anemone.medicinal_use: An infusion of the root can be used as an eye wash to treat twitches and eye poisoning. A wash of the pounded boiled root or of the leaves is applied externally to wounds, nosebleeds, sores, etc. A tea of the roots is used to treat headaches and dizziness. The root can be eaten to clear the throat.

Bearberry.medicinal_use: The leaves can be infused with oil, making a poultice to treat rashes and skin sores.
Bearberry.toxicity: The herb should not be used by children, pregnant women, or patients with kidney disease.
Bearberry.other_use: A yellowish-brown dye is obtained from the leaves. A grey-brown dye is obtained from the fruit.

Wild Ginger.edible_use: The dry root has an aromatic smell like mild pepper and ginger. The root is best harvested in autumn but is available year round. It can be dried for later use.
Wild Ginger.medicinal_use: The fresh leaves are applied as a poultice to wounds and inflammations, while a decoction or salve is applied to sores.

Lily of the Valley.medicinal_use: The leaves encourage the heart to beat more efficiently, and reduce blood volume. An ointment made from the roots is used to treat burns and prevent scar tissue.
Lily of the Valley.other_use: A yellow dye is obtained from the leaves in autumn.

Bleeding Heart.edible_use: In spring, the young leaves are edible when cooked.
Bleeding Heart.medicinal_use: Chewing on the rhizomes has a numbing effect on the surface of the gums, inner cheeks and tongue.
Bleeding Heart.toxicity: The plant is potentially poisonous and can also cause skin rashes.

Yellow Foxglove.medicinal_use: The leaves are used to treat certain heart complaints.
Yellow Foxglove.toxicity: All parts of the plant are poisonous.

Purple Coneflower.medicinal_use: The whole plant is beneficial in the treatment of sores, wounds, and burns. An infusion of the root can improve the immune system. It is harvested in the autumn and dried for later use.

Fairy Wings.edible_use: The young leaves are edible and taste best when they are soaked and then boiled in order to remove the bitterness.
Fairy Wings.medicinal_use: The leaves and flowers are used to lower blood sugar levels. The leaves are used as an aphrodisiac.

Alpine Strawberry.medicinal_use: The fruit can be applied externally to heal sunburns and whiten teeth. A tea made from the leaves can treat diarrhea. A poultice can be made from the powdered leaves mixed in oil, and then used to treat open sores. The roots are used to help stop diarrhea and chronic dysentery.

Wintergreen.edible_use: The fruit has a strong spicy taste of germolene. The fruit can also be used in pies or made into jams. The leaves can be eaten raw when the plant is young and can be used as tea.
Wintergreen.medicinal_use: An essential oil is extracted from the leaves. It contains methyl salicylate, which is closely related to aspirin and is an effective anti-inflammatory.

Geranium.other_use: The leaves are very aromatic and can be used as a source of geranium oil.

American Alumroot.medicinal_use: The root can be used as an external remedy for sores, wounds, vaginal discharges, and ulcers. It can be dried, ground into a powder, and sprinkled onto wounds. The root is harvested in the autumn and is dried for use in decoctions or as a powder.
American Alumroot.toxicity: It should be used with caution since excessive exposure irritates the stomach and can cause kidney and liver failure.

Day Lily.edible_use: The flowers are edible raw and are very rich in iron. The flowers can also be dried and used as a thickener in soups. The leaves and young shoots can be used as vegetables. The leaves need to be eaten while still very young since they quickly become fibrous.

Plantain Lilies.edible_use: The young leaves and leaf stems are edible after they are boiled.

Northern Blue Flag Iris.medicinal_use: The root can be taken internally as a tea to promote the excretion of excess body fluids. Some Native American tribes used the root as a protection against rattlesnakes.
Northern Blue Flag Iris.other_use: The leaves have been used to weave baskets and mats.
Northern Blue Flag Iris.toxicity: The fresh root is quite acrid and when taken internally may cause nausea and vomiting.

Ligularia.medicinal_use: The plant is used in Chinese medicine to treat anxiety, weakness, and menstrual disorders.

Chinese rhubarb.edible_use: The stem has a wonderful flavour once it is cooked and is a common ingredient in berry cakes.
Chinese rhubarb.other_use: The leaves can be used to make an insect spray.

Tansy.medicinal_use: The leaves are used as a poultice on swellings and some eruptive skin diseases. The plant is harvested as it is coming into flower.
Tansy.other_use: A green dye is obtained from the young shoots. The leaves and flowers can also be used to obtain a yellow dye.
Tansy.toxicity: In larger doses the plant can be poisonous.

Foamflower.medicinal_use: A tea made from the leaves is diuretic. It has been used as a mouthwash and as a wash for sore eyes. A tea made from the roots is used to treat diarrhea or sore mouths. The crushed roots can be used as a poultice on wounds.

Bloodroot.medicinal_use: Externally, the root is used in the treatment of skin diseases, warts, nasal polyps, and benign skin tumours. The crushed root has been applied to the body as an insect repellent.
Bloodroot.other_use: A red dye is obtained from the sap of the root. It was used as a face paint by the Native Americans.
Bloodroot.toxicity: The root is toxic. An excessive dose causes nausea and vomiting, and may prove fatal.

Bog Cranberry.edible_use: The fruit can be eaten raw or cooked. It is rich in vitamin C.
Bog Cranberry.medicinal_use: An infusion of the branches is used as a treatment for pleurisy.
